The National Guard has a long and storied history that dates back to colonial times. The first militia in the colonies was formed in Massachusetts in 1636 to provide defense against potential attacks from native tribes, French and Dutch colonists, and the Spanish. Over time, other colonies followed suit and established their own militias. 

During the Revolutionary War, militias played a critical role in the defense of the colonies against British forces. After the war, the militias were reorganized and became state militias, under the command of the governor of each respective state.

It wasn't until the Militia Act of 1903, also known as the Dick Act, was signed into law that the state militias were unified and formed into the National Guard, which is a dual-status force under both state and federal control.

In short, the National Guard has a long history that spans over 400 years, starting from the early colonial militias to its current form. Since its inception, the National Guard has served a vital role in protecting communities, providing defense against external threats, and responding to emergencies and natural disasters, among other duties.
